D5A0C617B6F044F89BA10F588DA4FA37.description: Explore applications related to fiber optics, lenses and human vision including polarization, the lens makers equation and total internal reflection.

82F798574A28412D81655B48AD876519.description: Apply Snell‚Äôs Law (ùëõùëõ1 sin ùúÉùúÉ1 = ùëõùëõ2 sin ùúÉùúÉ2), the magnification equation (ùëÄùëÄ = ‚Ñéùëñ/‚Ñéùëú= ‚àíùëëùëñ/ùëëùëú) and the lens equation (1/ùëì = 1/ùëëùëú+ 1/ùëëùëñ) to solve problems related to the refraction of waves.

ECF537DC407E4FDE8338A13D965769EE.description: Identify the properties, including type (real or virtual), attitude/orientation (upright or inverted), magnification (smaller, larger, or same size) and position (relative to the optical center) of images formed in converging and diverging lenses

5B985592133641BB9B671D29F3702AEA.description: Investigate image formation in converging and diverging lenses, including constructing ray diagrams.

EBFD551F7C7D4ED6970A2295B1FFA875.description: Relate refraction, and the refractive index of a medium, to the change in the speed and direction of waves at a boundary between different media.

FE1167DA0CC74D3DAEA8CFBDB8A14F6E.description: Examine the behavior of waves, including partial reflection and refraction, the critical angle and total internal reflection, at a boundary between different media. (

7AE5EDA133A0489694DA28F872282D5B.description: Pose scientific questions about how waves behave when they travel from one medium to another.

47A4FAC37A374909906898C84A257A71.description: Analyze, using physical materials, ray diagrams and mathematical equations, how waves refract at boundaries between different media.

846B584DFA2445CC9CB5D4AA375C3740.description: Describe the implications of wave-based technologies in furthering scientific understanding of phenomena such as Earth‚Äôs internal structure, the topography of the ocean floor and the rock cycle.

CBEE4FCDF32D41C8BA4F066D33EFBF0C.description: Apply the laws of reflection, the magnification equation (ùëÄùëÄ = ‚Ñéùëñ/‚Ñéùëú= ‚àíùëëùëñ/ùëëùëú) and the curved mirror equation (1/ùëì = 1/ùëëùëú+ 1/ùëëùëñ) tosolve problems related to the reflection of waves.

E00894120B7047EDA6045C4B2FAE0739.description: Identify the properties, including type (real or virtual), attitude/orientation (upright or inverted), magnification (smaller, larger or same size) and position (relative to the mirror surface or vertex), of images formed in plane, concave and convex mirrors.

37151B9D02AF4D42B09C4E2DB3AA69E1.description: Investigate image formation in plane, concave and convex mirrors, including constructing ray diagrams.

E253C3B92CF24A83BC66FD6EFE75889C.description: Provide examples of wave and particle reflection in everyday situations such as echoes, reverberation, room acoustics, radar, sonar, parabolic microphones, ultrasound, water waves, satellite dishes, billiard balls and ball-based sports.

B60F43EBBE7E4A18866E2D7FB61BFF65.description: Demonstrate the application of the law of reflection when a wave strikes a straight barrier and when a wave encounters the boundary between two different media.

DFCBA438AC124E469012D53B0F26CEE8.description: Compare the characteristics of specular (regular) and diffuse reflection of waves.

952E1E9C91BD43489CFF3ED0C657C29D.description: Investigate the behavior of waves as they strike parallel, oblique, and curved barriers.

80D3B8F78800454CBB75142C194C086F.description: Examine, using physical materials, ray diagrams and mathematical equations, how waves reflect from a variety of barriers.

FB5B91CE7920441E8D90E88E6D7D6090.description: Examine data or experimental results that provide evidence for the scientific theory of wave-particle duality of light.

29F4DE20E97C429BB29EB92260A5F4F4.description: Explore wave-related phenomena such as natural vibrations, forced vibrations, resonance and harmonics in the context of musical instruments and human hearing.

0C527E0EF6914B6190C0518D637C97AE.description: Provide examples of applications of the properties and characteristics of waves or electromagnetic radiation in various technologies (e.g., ultrasound, sonar, Doppler Effect, sonic booms, satellite dishes, microwaves, mobile phones, wireless routers, Bluetooth, radio waves, X-rays, radar and remote controls).

484D18B2966244DAA0EFEDC13F4FA68F.description: Observe and describe diffraction of waves through single and double slits and diffraction gratings.

83DDA36887414E89948BE15EBD61C58E.description: Illustrate constructive and destructive interference in one-, twoand three- dimensional waves, including the principle of superposition and standing waves, using point-source and straight-source waves

2040C921EB6E4FFA856DD0C335740D76.description: Solve problems related to speed, period, frequency and wavelength using the universal wave equation (ùë£ùë£ = ùúÜùúÜùëìùëì), the period-frequency relationship (T = 1/f) and the correct number of significant figures.

38F42DDB491A41118ED2EF04AC6EBE33.description: Trace the historical developments of technologies used to measure the speed of light and/or sound.

F4DE0085209142A89A2CDEE4D352BAA1.description: Describe the characteristics of the transmission of waves, including rectilinear propagation and the nature of the medium and its relationship to the speed of the wave.

9835554367CD45EFB96F3DC065564427.description: Identify characteristics of transverse and longitudinal waves including crests (positive pulse), troughs (negative pulse), compressions, rarefactions and the relationship between direction of vibration and energy transfer.

13597BAA3ED540C3A20D29EF2B040AE5.description: Rephrase questions about waves (e.g., What controls the frequency of a wave? What controls the speed of a wave? What happens when two or more waves meet?) into experimentally testable formats.

8B75D55EA23447EEB98D14192AC8A256.description: Communicate information about the properties and characteristics of waves using appropriate terminology, including medium, pulse, vibration, cycle, periodic motion, frequency, period, amplitude, phase and wavelength.

D67ADB013C3E486DBF4D8E70A0C1A7EF.description: Recognize that scientists understand waves as the transmission of energy originating from a vibrating source that determines the frequency and amplitude of the wave.

9FA331288D8D465AAC66967171187BB6.description: Examine First Nations and Metis perspectives on waves, including waves as carriers of energy.

0040046A95D946438F55596CB6F0F0E2.description: Pose questions about the nature and prevalence of waves in the world around us (e.g., What are waves? Where do we find waves in the world around us? Do all waves exhibit the same properties and behaviours? Why are waves important to study?).

0A973B5A0F594EA49D47A775086E6CA1.description: Investigate the properties and characteristics of one-, two- and threedimensional waves in at least three different media (e.g., springs, ropes, air and water).

83CB1A1EB6A045A692B0CCCCAE154DBE.description: Research how the reactants used and products formed through chemical reactions in industrial, mining and/or agricultural processes can affect human health and/or the health of the environment

B0C8E88927994EC0ABD376B3F7EDBC0E.description: Discuss the economic impact of the yield of chemical reactions with respect to maximizing product and profit and minimizing waste production.

AE71CCF5CA544F77AC87F149CEFA9A99.description: Predict how to maximize the yield of a particular chemical process.

EBB6D01A06514C0DB8CC8697029D7D0F.description: Explain how actual yield differs from theoretical yield using the concept of sources of error.

53DB6A7ABFC84AE6857C614B8491DD1C.description: Compare the theoretical and actual yield for a variety of chemical reactions by calculating the percent yield.

371847DFB7C446FDBE4E88237664F699.description: Determine the limiting and excess reagents in a variety of chemical reactions through stoichiometric calculations and experimentation.

88C6139F3FB944989CF30FC5104BE81E.description: Communicate results of experiments using narrative and formal lab reports.

96F6CA581DEF463B9EC07792C3A7410F.description: Design and carry out experiments to support stoichiometric hypotheses using appropriate instruments to collect data accurately and precisely.

C645DD562B354396815044F89AD6A0B2.description: Perform stoichiometric calculations to predict the outcomes (e.g., concentration, mass, volume, number of particles and energy transferred) of chemical reactions, using the correct units and correct number of significant figures.

30D166BD312F4F77A001AE21BAD6FD1C.description: Relate the use of the mole to the coefficients in a balanced chemical equation, and compare this to mass and volume as measurable quantities.

3C245D97B70E490698BCBCAD0F7F92D0.description: Determine the relative numbers of moles of each substance in a variety of chemical reactions using balanced chemical equations.

F57BA44397CE460CBE23329E5BE6E9A2.description: Use stoichiometry to determine the relative amounts of substances consumed and produced in chemical reactions.

C90A92EC0C8344EC833D6B1C1E5BAFEC.description: Use stoichiometry to determine the relative amounts of substances consumed and produced in chemical reactions.

8FC456785F7243738A384867C6F5F738.description: Research the use of solutions in industrial, mining and agricultural processes.

D6365B07A5A74D5ABCE256534421CCD1.description: Prepare solutions of known concentration using molarity and dilution calculations.

221DD2833E494459AC2ADDE6175A9D2C.description: Perform molar conversions, including mass to mole, number of particles to mole, volume to mole, concentration of a solution to mole and their inverse operations, using the correct number of significant figures

FFDA46D256404A5FB4DA3F6002B14507.description: Calculate the molar mass of various molecular and ionic compounds

343D0BED5FFC4CC2903D08BDB66D6A15.description: Celebrate mole day on 10/23 or 6/02 by bringing a multiple of a mole of substance to school, consuming a mole of a substance and creating and/or sharing cartoons, articles, pictures or songs relevant to the mole.

DBB8352FF81749568409F403BD0DA1B1.description: Outline how individuals such as Avogadro, Berzelius, Davy, GayLussac, Proust and Dalton have contributed to modern understanding of the composition of compounds.

C5F41FF0879740EC97FD851E8870E5AB.description: Explain why chemists use the mole to represent the amount of a substance.

F5F9D67DFE2F4C8393A2467BE517F61A.description: Provide examples to demonstrate the size of the Avogadro constant (6.02 x 1023) in relation to common items such as coins, water drops, sand grains and marbles.

AE1BF7E34983452B8E235B77B732C690.description: Relate counting by weighing to the sale of a granular product such as grain or gravel, the purchase of bulk foods, rolled coin deposits at the bank and purchasing propane for a barbeque.

FD05098BEEFF4B5090811D7AB6307FD9.description: Relate counting by weighing to the sale of a granular product such as grain or gravel, the purchase of bulk foods, rolled coin deposits at the bank and purchasing propane for a barbeque.

9934C0A889844F1A8BEE8B12F24197E3.description: Pose questions about how to measure quantities of substances that are not readily countable.

25041E54B1C34F3789FBF5259B9288BD.description: Construct an understanding of the mole as a unit for measuring the amount of substance.

29991199F14E4053983D56DE45E55D49.description: Research how industrial, mining and/or agricultural processes involve chemical reactions.

7E462BCB708D4D43B5C498C8FD2FDFC2.description: Describe how the outcomes of various chemical reactions may benefit or harm living organisms and affect the environment.

66B3F4794A8140F2B29386191D4BB38F.description: Analyze and compare the fuel consumed and carbon output of various combustion reactions (e.g., methane, propane, octane and ethanol).

A98137E45A7242BCA958B28BC503A19D.description: Select and apply proper techniques for handling and disposing of lab materials, as outlined in Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS 2015) standards, and interpret Safety Data Sheets (SDSs).

3FF6DF8249A34ABEA9B078AA2EB107FE.description: Design, and carry out if practical, an investigation to demonstrate the difference between a complete and incomplete combustion reaction.

83E744A55F9949C5ABD744440DF0359D.description: Distinguish between the products of complete and incomplete combustion reactions and potential consequences of the latter for living things and the environment

B074BC8B553B4BDB885D7D752F631384.description: Predict products of double-replacement reactions, including acid-base neutralization reactions, and precipitate formation using solubility rules

182312A70EDC4FF8A905703373F91D8E.description: Determine the feasibility of single-replacement reactions based on the activity series of metals and/or non-metals.

86E65568637E4084922BD45F0F2A93B8.description: Predict products of synthesis and decomposition reactions given the reactants.

20458A76BC8642329F6418D6936A81D4.description: Explain the importance of skeleton equations, balanced equations and IUPAC nomenclature in communicating understanding of chemical reactions.

AD4B689AEA4F4D6A8F9CFA69053081AC.description: Represent synthesis, decomposition, combustion, singlereplacement and double-replacement (including acid base neutralization) reactions using atomic models, other manipulatives, skeleton equations, balanced chemical equations and International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) nomenclature.

4F0C08EC98554F71AAF6BF7CA0222E54.description: Observe and analyze synthesis, decomposition, combustion, single-replacement and double-replacement (including acid base neutralization) reactions.

D475A76D558348B1B33D94D92FA7C47E.description: Predict products of the five basic types of chemical reactions and evaluate the impact of these reactions on society and the environment.

10586295DB314783B3C19AD14CE73517.description: Compare the fuel consumed and heat energy output of various combustion reactions involving common fuels (e.g., methane, propane, octane and ethanol).

188B303C31744A0DB8CD05F5401699FE.description: Design, create and evaluate the effectiveness of a cold pack and/or heat pack given the goal of having no excess reactants remaining at reaction completion.

E43507A158EC447B892E3630C5B2A729.description: Compare the quantity of heat involved in the use of various commercially available cold and/or heat packs.

928789779C774A00B6DA2F61BB665928.description: Calculate the molar heat of reaction associated with dissolving ionic compounds in a solution.

A573F022269E4C5EAFEFBD955A4DE0DC.description: Discuss the importance of analyzing the quantities of heat involved in chemical reactions.

8DFFFCD7501C4FA8846606B48458E594.description: Explain why the actual heat of reaction differs from the theoretical heat of reaction, with reference to sources of error and percent error calculations.

D3750784EE6D41A5B300992FC7D7C197.description: Calculate the theoretical quantity of heat absorbed or released in specific exothermic and/or endothermic reactions, including combustion reactions, using various quantities of reactants given the heat of reaction.

4DB1FEE33755454CA492DD314FCB022F.description: Measure, using a thermometer or temperature probe, and record the temperature change in an exothermic and/or endothermic chemical reaction.

86960804931A4A0F902C0AC8453CB31E.description: Research the historical development of thermodynamics, including significant discoveries and inventions, and the contributions of engineers and scientists such as Carnot, Maxwell, Boltzmann, Lord Kelvin and Gibbs.

CF729CD522564A2FB8E91499B6B985C8.description: Distinguish between endothermic and exothermic chemical reactions, including those that occur in solutions.

95EFA885A8DE4886AC59B21C5D161FA6.description: Determine the quantities of heat involved in chemical reactions through experimentation and calculation.

39D0694EF2EB400FB8D1C39F6AD14383.description: Discuss how the anomalous properties (e.g., density, phase and thermodynamic properties) of water, as compared with other liquids, affect the environment and Earth‚Äôs climate

CC3AA98ADEF7463981CA8011EBCFA6FD.description: Investigate effects of the thermal expansion and contraction of matter in technological applications such as road, bridge and building design, plumbing, power line construction and industrial engineering.

06F51F03EF9740FBBBB2B309984BAC53.description: Explore, qualitatively and/or quantitatively, the expansion and contraction of matter during heat transfer or temperature change.

F157BC124D9C4ED1805BF1EBDBC0B223.description: Examine traditional and contemporary applications of heat transfer such as heating a drum skin, using heat to make copper tools, energy control in buildings, heat pumps and insulated and moisture wicking clothing.

F26E0276D5AA4050BA4CAB52C22B3811.description: Calculate and experimentally verify the amount of heat exchanged and final temperature reached when mixing two known quantities of known substances, and suggest sources of experimental error and improvements to experimental design.

B4099218D4434A1B8AC42119D1E3FEF4.description: Calculate the quantity of heat (???? = ?????????????), specific heat capacity, latent heat of fusion (???? = ????????????) and latent heat of vaporization (???? = ????????????) during changes of state, using the correct number of significant figures.

7D1AE602168641A09610CB66A94F08A3.description: Use appropriate technologies such as temperature probes and calorimeters safely when collecting data

6898D6329968448482E55CDE64FF0834.description: Construct a heating or cooling curve for water, or other substances, using personally collected data and appropriate graphing techniques or software.

5EF03E8BB37443499B2AEF296534E42A.description: Construct a heating or cooling curve for water, or other substances, using personally collected data and appropriate graphing techniques or software.

BDEE7BF084A1419D8DEBC2428C26A4F1.description: Compare, in quantitative terms, the heat capacities of some common materials, including water, and explain how heat capacity can influence choices of materials used in the development of technologies related to clothing, food and shelter.

B0CAFD604FDD4C8DAF51370B39A89BA3.description: Measure some physical properties of water, such as density at various temperatures, specific heat capacity and latent heat of fusion and latent heat of vaporization.

5B4BEAA3D1D2468398B7247DEB8E2DEB.description: Determine the latent heat of fusion and/or latent heat of vaporization of various substances using a calorimeter.

66FA59970C4F49FF8742295461A06693.description: Measure the specific heat capacity of various metals using a calorimeter.

98960363C6074A3BB463184F952F5748.description: Discuss how the concept of a closed system and the law of conservation of energy underlie the study of heat and heat transfer

CB7E3B0474CE4D4C9C11FB547C68951C.description: Explore the importance of heat and fire for First Nations and M√©tis peoples, and how they use their understanding of heat transfer to solve practical problems related to cooking and shelter.

C1C6376AA7E24274A86F2173AC1788AB.description: Distinguish between heat and temperature using the kinetic molecular theory of matter.

9B71B9ECBFDE48A0A07C4E017C3DEAC6.description: Analyze, qualitatively and quantitatively, the effect of heat on matter during temperature changes and changes of state using kinetic molecular theory.

B515CCEA641A40E282EA8F29BC482AFB.description: Construct a tool (e.g., rubric, checklist, self-evaluation form or peer-evaluation form) to assess the process and products involved in a student-directed study.

1243CE2A3ECE441DA36FE4AEF4C132F8.description: Share the results of student-directed research through a display, presentation, performance, demonstration, song, game, commercial, fine art representation, video or research paper.

7DF42E8A16284E248B58AFBCE8A94F88.description: Debate an issued related to physical science, including developing materials to support the arguments for and against a position.

572D651A1B5F445F90984F10F3A5643D.description: Design, construct and evaluate the effectiveness of a device, model or technique that demonstrates the scientific principles underlying a concept related to Physical Science 20.

150F140A269049B2B7F79C846412D594.description: Assemble and reflect on a portfolio that demonstrates an understanding of a physical science topic of interest to the student.

4289151F382444D0BBFCAF9BD3B74384.description: Carry out an experiment following established scientific protocols to investigate a question of interest related to one or more of the topics of Physical Science 20.

B93CD2096A624FC3BB3D5973085A94C9.description: Design a scientific investigation related to a topic of study in Physical Science 20 that includes a testable question, a hypothesis, an experimental design that will test the hypothesis and detailed procedures for collecting and analyzing data.

4B28D6300BEF4BA1B4628B7AC8A44B1E.description: Create and carry out a plan to explore one or more topics of personal interest relevant to Physical Science 20 in depth.

5D6B1815EE4E4941996CF074590DB302.description: Develop a plan to attain your dream job in the physical science field.

8B17FA056DAF451FB47A42298FF8ACE7.description: Communicate research findings related to physical science occupations through a display, brochure, video, presentation software, website or orally

8CAF49E047644BA7A0E314AFA92F28F8.description: Interview or connect with others to discuss physical science related occupations

39E3A161D177409790AA46C6585976D0.description: Reflect upon personal suitability or non-suitability for a specific physical-science related occupation considering criteria such as: initial and continuing educational requirements; duties and skills required for this occupation; the work environment, including typical hours and shifts worked and typical locations; current wages received in Saskatchewan and how these compare to the rest of Canada; physical, mental and emotional stresses related to this occupation; workplace hazards and safety considerations; other occupations with which they interact; professional and/or licensing requirements in Canada and Saskatchewan; and future trends impacting the occupation.

CB574721E3634C2C9ACEA0507059ACA6.description: Examine the roles, responsibilities, educational qualifications and personal and professional qualities common to people involved in physical-science related jobs.

B53FF3E0D43E434BB95282EC1F012FA9.description: Identify which physical science related occupations are facing shortages and which are oversubscribed locally, regionally and/or nationally.

45A414B3CDA34D428BC5FB3711869DFD.description: Explore connection between topics in Physical Science 20 and occupations of personal interest.

3090BC4ABF464D15A0A757824FEF3906.description: Generate a list of occupations that require a background in physical science through research and/or participation in events such as a career fair or job shadow

936381789A4343DBA30D994939842309.description: Analyze and explore physical science related occupations in Saskatchewan, Canada and the world.
